Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (general landlor.raw_text: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (general landlord–tenant provisions)
Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (general landlor.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential tenancy carries an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment by which a landlord must not substantially interfere with the tenant’s possession or use and enjoyment of the leased premises. The covenant protects tenants from material interferences with their possession, use, or beneficial enjoyment of the premises that are caused or allowed by the landlord. The covenant applies whether the interference is by the landlord or by those over whom the landlord has control (see authorities cited below).

Osborn v. Cottrell, 34 Mass. App. Ct. 40.raw_text: Osborn v. Cottrell, 34 Mass. App. Ct. 408 (1993) (discussing landlord obligations and tenant remedies)*
Osborn v. Cottrell, 34 Mass. App. Ct. 40.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential tenancy carries an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment by which a landlord must not substantially interfere with the tenant’s possession or use and enjoyment of the leased premises. The covenant protects tenants from material interferences with their possession, use, or beneficial enjoyment of the premises that are caused or allowed by the landlord. Osborn v. Cottrell, 34 Mass. App. Ct. 40.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt is entirely about workers’ compensation liens and third‑party settlements under G.L. c. 152, § 15. It does not discuss residential tenancies, covenants of quiet enjoyment, landlord obligations, or tenant remedies. Accordingly, this case does not provide authority for the stated proposition about an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts residential tenancies.
Osborn v. Cottrell, 34 Mass. App. Ct. 40.relevant_excerpt: On appeal, Liberty argues that, because it did not consent to accepting less than full reimbursement from the proceeds of the third-party action, the judge was not authorized to approve the proposed settlement. Liberty points out that the statutory language does not invest the judge with the authority to choose what amount shall be refunded, unless agreed upon by the workers’ compensation insurer. We think that this construction is supported by both the pertinent legislative history and the case law interpreting the statute.
